results.headline: What It Hurts to Remember Becomes Convenient to Forget
results.summary_short: A full appreciation of Lucrecia Martel’s elegant, rain-soaked film, “The Headless Woman,” requires the concentration and eye for detail of a forensic detective.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Headless Woman

results.headline: A Speed-Eating Course on the Bestial Appetites of Humanity
results.summary_short: “Taxidermia” produces nightmarish horror and formal beauty in a surreal, Central European blend.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Taxidermia

results.headline: Forces of Nature, Including Children
results.summary_short: “Ponyo,” the latest masterwork from Hayao Miyazaki, places emphasis on the natural world, its tumults and fragility.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ponyo

results.headline: A Harsh Hello for Visitors From Space
results.summary_short: This smart, swift film takes the axiomatic question of the U.F.O. genre — what are they going to do to us? — and inverts it.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of District 9

results.headline: Some Unexpected Behavior Therapy for the Not-So-Great Dictator
results.summary_short: A failure of nerve sinks Dani Levy’s film “My Führer: The Truly Truest Truth About Adolf Hitler.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Fuhrer

results.headline: So Sorry, I Lost My Clothes Years Ago
results.summary_short: “The Time Traveler’s Wife” is an often ridiculous, awkward, unsatisfying and dour melodramatic adaptation of the novel.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Time Traveler's Wife

results.headline: A Couple of Hustlers, Hustling Into Love
results.summary_short: Ashton Kutcher exudes a goofy, rakish charm in “Spread,” but the movie doesn’t attach to him a coherent story.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Spread

results.headline: Guys With Guitars, Trading Riffs and Metaphysical Musings
results.summary_short: “It Might Get Loud” is a group portrait of three musicians and a free-form historical and philosophical essay on the instrument that unites them.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of It Might Get Loud

results.headline: Bringing Up Dead Baby
results.summary_short: The horror film “Grace” plays with ideas of mother love, obsessive child rearing and liberal spinelessness.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Grace

results.headline: Stimulus Package: Crass for Clunkers
results.summary_short: “The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard” is a grubby-looking comedy about the art of the sale.
results.display_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard

results.headline: Fugitives Up on the Roof Then Out on the Road
results.summary_short: The small, sometimes confusing movie is a knowing homage to Jean-Luc Godard.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I'm Gonna Explode

results.headline: Planetary Reflections
results.summary_short: “Earth Days” is a sedate chronicle of the highs and lows of the environmental movement.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Earth Days

results.headline: In Their Twilight Years, Like Moths to a Flame
results.summary_short: “Cloud 9” is a whistling-past-the-graveyard tale of two elderly Berliners taking a last chance at love.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cloud 9

results.headline: A Janitor’s Flights of Fancy
results.summary_short: The hat makes the man in the Jordanian film “Captain Abu Raed,” though that whimsical notion is only a starting point for this efficiently told tale.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Captain Abu Raed

results.headline: Sung Heroes
results.summary_short: “Bandslam” may not entirely break new teen-movie ground, but it does offer intriguing glimpses of performers ready to bolt from the Disney stable.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bandslam

results.headline: Entwined at a Japanese Shrine, the Nobility and Horrific Brutality of War
results.summary_short: “Yasukuni” addresses a passionately contested snarl of issues with a calm, nuanced ethical curiosity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Yasukuni

results.headline: Good Guys Meet Bad Guys; Cue Explosions
results.summary_short: “G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra,” spun off from the Hasbro-toy world, offers gagging laughs, discount special effects, hoo-ha din and interchangeable action figures.
results.display_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra

results.headline: Cultures and Sexes Clash in the Aftermath of a Rape in Turkey
results.summary_short: “Bliss” observes the collision of two cultures, one ancient, the other modern, in contemporary Turkey.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bliss

results.headline: Two for the Stove
results.summary_short: “Julie & Julia” proceeds with such ease and charm that its audacity is easy to miss.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Julie & Julia

results.headline: Navigating the Shoals Between Twins
results.summary_short: Just what is or isn’t someone else’s business is one of the questions Andrew Bujalski and his characters explore in “Beeswax.”
